description: Enterprise techniques used by BRONZE BUTLER, ATT&CK group G0060 v1.0
name: BRONZE BUTLER (G0060)

techniques.comment: BRONZE BUTLER has used net user /domain to identify account information.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER downloader code has included "0" characters at the end of the file to inflate the file size in a likely attempt to evade anti-virus detection.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER malware xxmm contains a UAC bypass tool for privilege escalation.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER uses the command-line interface.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to perform credential dumping.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has compressed data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.[2]
Several BRONZE BUTLER tools encode data with base64 when posting it to a C2 server.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has compressed and encrypted data into password-protected RAR archives prior to exfiltration.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from local systems.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has exfiltrated files stolen from file shares.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER downloads encoded payloads and decodes them on the victim.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.[3]
BRONZE BUTLER has exploited Microsoft Word vulnerability CVE-2014-4114 for execution.[3]
BRONZE BUTLER has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.[2]
The BRONZE BUTLER uploader or malware the uploader uses command to delete the RAR archives after they have been exfiltrated.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has given malware the same name as an existing file on the file share server to cause users to unwittingly launch and install the malware on additional systems.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has created forged Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) and Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets to maintain administrative access.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used PowerShell for execution.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used a batch script that adds a Registry Run key to establish malware persistence.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used various tools to download files, including DGet (a similar tool to wget).[2]
BRONZE BUTLER typically use ping and Net to enumerate systems.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used at and schtasks to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used a tool to capture screenshots.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used VBS, VBE, and batch scripts for execution.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to infect victims.[3]
BRONZE BUTLER malware has used HTTP for C2.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has used net time to check the local time on a target system.[2]
BRONZE BUTLER has attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Word attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.[3]
BRONZE BUTLER's MSGET downloader uses a dead drop resolver to access malicious payloads.[2]
